form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Explanation of Paternity Evaluation Results, NARA, 7/27/2023

full_text: Screened by NARA, 7/27/2023 7017 Albert Pick Road Greensboro, NC 27409-9654 GENETIC DESIGN Explanation of Paternity Evaluation Results Paternity testing involves the identification of genetic markers in blood obtained from the parties in disputed parentage cases. The genetic markers are represented by groups of chemical substances which prove the presence of specific genes in defined genetic systems. Blood is a mixture of cell types in a supporting liquid called plasma. The test systems most frequently used in paternity testing can be categorized by the blood component utilized. 1. Red Blood Cells. Genetic markers on red blood cells are called antigens and they are identified by their reaction with reagents called antibodies. ABO and Rh are examples of blood groups in this category. 2. Red Blood Cell Enzymes and Plasma Proteins. Genetic markers in this category are identified by placing the liquid substances of the blood on a supporting surface and allowing them to migrate as charged particles in an electric field (electrophoresis). Under these conditions, the individual groups separate into bands or spots which allow their identification. 3. HLA (human Jeukocyte antigens): White blood cells provide a convenient cell for the identification of a large and diverse group of substances called histocompatibility antigens. The typing of these antigens (HLA) is used to match organ transplant donors and recipients and constitutes one of the most useful systems tested in disputed paternity cases. The test results are analyzed for exclusions by assessing genetic inconsistencies between the mother, child, and the alleged father (that is, blood groups or DNA fragments in the child that cannot be explained as having been inherited from either the mother or alleged father). By using combinations of the above genetic systems, an average of 98-99 out of 100 men falsely accused of paternity can be excluded. If an exclusion is not found, the inclusionary genetic evidence is quantitated in the form of a paternity index which combines the rarity of the blood groups potentially shared between the alleged father and the child with genetic aspects of their inheritance. The paternity index is reported as an odds ratio which tells how many times more likely the alleged father is to be the biological father than a man in the unrelated, random population of a similar ethnic background. The results are also reported as a probability of paternity. This calculation is made by using Bayes' theorem to combine the paternity index (scientific evidence) with a neutral, unbiased assessment of the subjective evidence (0.5 prior probability).
